GitHub
2021-06-02 07:39:09

[cucumber/cucumber-rails] Comment on #515

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/515#issuecomment-853085110|Comment on #515 Upgrade cucumber dependency to work with cucumber 6>
Somewhere in one of the tests we write a cuke `"the client requests GET /{word}"` this now needs amending a tiny amount to `"the client requests GET \/{word}"` ``` the client requests GET /{word} ^ Alternative may not be empty. If you did not mean to use an alternative you can use '\/' to escape the the '/' (Cucumber::CucumberExpressions::AlternativeMayNotBeEmpty) ```
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2021-06-02 07:42:17

[cucumber/cucumber-rails] Comment on #515

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/515#issuecomment-853087566|Comment on #515 Upgrade cucumber dependency to work with cucumber 6>
&gt; Somewhere in one of the tests we write a cuke &gt; `"the client requests GET /{word}"` &gt; &gt; this now needs amending a tiny amount to &gt; &gt; `"the client requests GET \/{word}"` &gt; &gt; ``` &gt; the client requests GET /{word} &gt; ^ &gt; Alternative may not be empty. &gt; If you did not mean to use an alternative you can use '\/' to escape the the '/' (Cucumber::CucumberExpressions::AlternativeMayNotBeEmpty) &gt; &gt; ``` Yeap, did it right before your comment, thanks a lot :) Regarding Rails 6.0, you would not to support cucumber 6 with rails 6.0 on purpose? Or did you notice something that would prevent us to do so?
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2021-06-02 07:55:41

[cucumber/cucumber-rails] Comment on #515

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/515#issuecomment-853098584|Comment on #515 Upgrade cucumber dependency to work with cucumber 6>
Semi on purpose. A while back we started to try trim down our support matrix. And we came up with a semi-ok set of rules. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/blob/main/.github/workflows/build.yml#L13-L18">https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/blob/main/.github/workflows/build.yml#L13-L18</a> Obviously over time this has then extended to other gems/versions. but basically if it's not rails 5.2 or the latest 6.x we don't support it with the latest gems. To try and kick people to one of those versions. So we then started staggering capybara and cucumber versions accordingly.
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2021-06-02 07:59:34

[cucumber/cucumber-rails] Comment on #515

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/515#issuecomment-853101670|Comment on #515 Upgrade cucumber dependency to work with cucumber 6>
<a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a> <a href="https://github.com/aurelien-reeves">@aurelien-reeves</a> I'd suggest removing the parts of that comment that are inconsistent with the versions specified below.
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2021-06-02 07:59:55

[cucumber/cucumber-rails] Comment on #515

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/515#issuecomment-853101998|Comment on #515 Upgrade cucumber dependency to work with cucumber 6>
Ok, thanks. I would suggest to let rails 5.2 with cucumber &lt; 6, but support rails 6.0 with cucumber &lt; 7 like rails 6.1 if it works well I noticed also that it seems we are not yet compatible with ruby 3. I will open a PR for that soon I guess ;)
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>

2021-06-02 08:12:08

[cucumber/cucumber-rails] Comment on #515

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/515#issuecomment-853111723|Comment on #515 Upgrade cucumber dependency to work with cucumber 6>
This: `2.4 -&gt; Only use legacy rails versions (5.0/5.1)` Versus this: `- { ruby: '2.4', gemfile: 'rails_5_2' }` Same for `2.5` and `2.6` Comments always get out of date. Better to remove them.
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2021-06-02 08:14:34

[cucumber/cucumber-rails] Comment on #515

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/515#issuecomment-853113763|Comment on #515 Upgrade cucumber dependency to work with cucumber 6>
That looks good to me. With ruby 2.4 we want to check only rails 5.0 and rails 5.1, so we exclude rails 5.2, rails 6.0 and rails 6.1 from ruby 2.4 in the matrix. The same for other versions of ruby
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2021-06-02 08:45:55

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/516|#516 Support Ruby 3>
<p>Attempt to add support for Ruby 3.</p> <p>I've added a new entry in the build matrix. Ruby 3 is only properly supported with Rails 6.1.</p> <p>I have updated the runtime dependencies in the gemspec. I have tried other ways without success.</p>

[cucumber/cucumber-rails] Pull request opened by aurelien-reeves

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/517|#517 Add support for Ruby 3>
<p>Attempt to add support for Ruby 3.</p> <p>I've added a new entry in the build matrix. Ruby 3 is only properly supported with Rails 6.1.</p> <p>I have updated the runtime dependencies in the gemspec. I have tried other ways without success.</p>

Hi <a href="https://github.com/JoeSSS">@JoeSSS</a>, Thanks for your making your first contribution to Cucumber, and welcome to the Cucumber committers team! You can now push directly to this repo and all other repos under the cucumber organization! 🍾 In return for this generous offer we hope you will: • ✅ Continue to use branches and pull requests. When someone on the core team approves a pull request (yours or someone else's), you're welcome to merge it yourself. • 💚 Commit to setting a good example by following and upholding our <a href="https://cucumber.io/conduct">code of conduct</a> in your interactions with other collaborators and users. • 💬 Join the <a href="http://cucumber.io/support#slack">community Slack channel</a> to meet the rest of the team and make yourself at home. • ℹ️ Don't feel obliged to help, just do what you can if you have the time and the energy. • 🙋 Ask if you need anything. We're looking for feedback about how to make the project more welcoming, so please tell us! On behalf of the Cucumber core team, Aslak Hellesøy Creator of Cucumber

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>

2021-06-04 05:43:30

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1544

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1544#issuecomment-854691416|Comment on #1544 Upgrade messages and gherkin to bring new 'jsonschema messages'>
&gt; <a href="https://github.com/aurelien-reeves">@aurelien-reeves</a> this might be a blocker on getting my PR complete (As I would need a patched version of messages to the new 19.0.3 (Not yet created). Which seems from this PR to require lots of changes. In conjuction with `cucumber-ruby-core` and `cucumber-ruby-wire`, this PR is actually ready. If you execute the tests using <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/219">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core#219</a>, they are passing. So the question is: 1. do we agree with releasing a cucumber-ruby with messages represented as plain ruby hashes with camelCase keys to release the fixes for rules asap? 2. do we wait for messages with DTOs instead of hashes and delay fixes for rules for some time? 3. do we fix Gherkin@18.1 which rely on messages@15 to release the fix for rules more quickly, but make us deploy a fix for a past version which we are not use to? I must say that I don't really have a favorite. If we go for 2. waiting for messages to have a release with DTOs, I can organize myself to be super-focus on that next week to try releasing it as quickly as possible.
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-06-04 05:46:12

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1542

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1542#issuecomment-856037355|Comment on #1542 Improvement of welcoming documentation>
&gt; This looks great! I wonder if we should explain more about the relationship with the core gem, and how to set up a development environment that includes both. I though that it would be more relevant in the `core` repo, or maybe in an ARCHITECTURE.md shared across the cucumber-ruby repositories. Or maybe in the wiki? &gt; There's also nothing mentioned (unless I missed it) about the standards we expect from PR submissions - TDD/test coverage, rubocop linting etc. That might be helpful. Actually I wanted to put that in the PR template. And remain pretty gentle with this. There are not too many PR, we can guide contributors through "our" expected standards as part of the reviews. That would let the welcoming document neater. &gt; We could also explicitly point out that we full-time maintainers are available for 1:1 pairing sessions to coach people with their submissions. I'd happily make my calendly link available in this document. Yes, that could be interesting indeed 👍 To sum-up, my strategy here is to to avoid the README and the CONTRIBUTING to be overwhelming but to distill the info all along the process a new contributor would follow when sending a first PR.
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-06-07 09:30:28

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1542

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1542#issuecomment-856085270|Comment on #1542 Improvement of welcoming documentation>
Yes, I like the layered approach, making this entry-point doc not too long and leaving depth to other docs. From having paired with <a href="https://github.com/eduardrudko">@eduardrudko</a> on <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/218">his PR</a>, I could see that the two-gem situation caused him some confusion at first, so for example the setup with the environment variables to override Gemfile paths needs to be documented. Maybe instead of documenting it we should just bite the bullet and merge the two repos into a one little cucumber-ruby monorepo with both gems in it?
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-06-07 09:33:36

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1542

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1542#issuecomment-856087341|Comment on #1542 Improvement of welcoming documentation>
&gt; Actually I wanted to put that in the PR template. And remain pretty gentle with this. Oh yes, I agree we should be gentle and constructive. I think that setting expectations can be kind and supportive - because it will be frustrating for someone to make a PR and then be told later "could you write some tests for this please?"
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>

2021-06-09 09:38:06

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Issue opened by jim-edwards

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1551|#1551 Cucumber "Transform" replacment, ParameterType, does not work for all use-cases, espeically Tables>
<p>We have a Transform that loops through table entries and executes functions if the column itself contains some specific data (IE, its based on the result, not the regex). I am struggling to see how this could be done with ParameterType, doesn't seem possible.. Here is a sample of the code for reference:</p> <pre><code>Transform /table:.**/ do |table| table.map_headers! { |header| header.downcase.to_sym } table.hashes.each do |row| row.each do |column, value| if row[column] =~ /_CONFIG_/ row[column]=TestSys::Easy.current_session.helper.add_config_settings(row[column]) end if row[column] =~ /_UNIQ_/ row[column]=TestSys::Easy.current_session.helper.replace_uniq_strings(row[column]) end if row[column] =~ /_LOCAL_/ row[column]=TestSys::Easy.current_session.helper.add_local_settings(row[column]) end if row[column] =~ /_FEATURE_/ row[column]=TestSys::Easy.current_session.helper.add_feature_settings(row[column]) end if row[column] =~ /_RANDOMHEX_/ row[column]=TestSys::Easy.current_session.helper.add_hex_string(row[column]) end if row[column] =~ /_RANDOMALPHANUMERIC_/ row[column]=TestSys::Easy.current_session.helper.process_random_number(row[column]) end if row[column].include? '\s' row[column] = row[column].gsub('\s', ' ') end end end table end </code></pre> <p>The above allows the following values to be replaced in steps:</p> <pre><code>And I assign the LOCAL variable name "TEST" the value "auto_RANDOMALPHANUMERIC_5" </code></pre> <p>The above transform will do a match, find the RANDOMALPHANUMERIC because its set the value and call the function above, replacing it with the return value from the function.</p> <p>It also works in a table as you show, for example:</p> <pre><code>Then I fill in the fields below: | id | value | | personalEmail | &lt;a href="mailto:noreply@test.com"&gt;noreply@test.com&lt;/a&gt; | | @Field1 | _RANDOM_15 | </code></pre> <p>Both of those appear to work. Note that neither use the "Example" framework of a test case to execute the same Scenario multiple times.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-06-09 15:57:48

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1551

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1551#issuecomment-858154561|Comment on #1551 Cucumber "Transform" replacment, ParameterType, does not work for all use-cases, espeically Tables>
Thanks for writing this up Jim. I suspect that the `Transform` call here is not providing the replacement for the step `And I assign the LOCAL variable name "TEST" the value "auto_RANDOMALPHANUMERIC_5"` but only for the data table values. I expect you have another step def somewhere that's also calling `TestSys::Easy.current_session.helper.process_random_number`
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-06-09 16:04:12

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1551

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1551#issuecomment-858156943|Comment on #1551 Cucumber "Transform" replacment, ParameterType, does not work for all use-cases, espeically Tables>
You're right that parameter types only work for regular steps, not for data tables. I think your workaround for now would be to refactor to extract a helper method out of your `Transform` function: ``` Transform /table:.*/ do |table| expand_placeholders_in table end module Helpers def expand_placeholders_in(table) table.map_headers! { |header| header.downcase.to_sym } table.hashes.each do |row| row.each do |column, value| if row[column] =~ /_CONFIG_/ row[column]=TestSys::Easy.current_session.helper.add_config_settings(row[column]) end if row[column] =~ /_UNIQ_/ row[column]=TestSys::Easy.current_session.helper.replace_uniq_strings(row[column]) end if row[column] =~ /_LOCAL_/ row[column]=TestSys::Easy.current_session.helper.add_local_settings(row[column]) end if row[column] =~ /_FEATURE_/ row[column]=TestSys::Easy.current_session.helper.add_feature_settings(row[column]) end if row[column] =~ /_RANDOMHEX_/ row[column]=TestSys::Easy.current_session.helper.add_hex_string(row[column]) end if row[column] =~ /_RANDOMALPHANUMERIC_/ row[column]=TestSys::Easy.current_session.helper.process_random_number(row[column]) end if row[column].include? '\s' row[column] = row[column].gsub('\s', ' ') end end end table end World(Helpers) ``` Then, you can use that helper function to manually expand the placeholders everywhere you take a table as a parameter: ``` Given /a step that takes a table:/ do |table| expand_placeholders_in table ... # do stuff with the expanded table data end ``` That would at least allow you to get rid of the dependency on `Transform` and upgrade to a more modern version of Cucumber while we figure out how to implement this functionality again.
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-06-15 17:47:34

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Issue opened by pgundlupetvenkatesh

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1553|#1553 Scenario outline Table Value is Getting Cloned on Each Run>
<p><strong>Describe the bug</strong><br /> Scenario Outline table value gets appended to the previous iteration value when the table values are same using <code>&amp;lt;&amp;lt;</code> operator</p> <p><strong>To Reproduce</strong><br /> Feature file -</p> <pre><code>Feature: Testing City Names Scenario Outline: And I live in '&amp;lt;city&amp;gt;' City And I am not from '&amp;lt;city&amp;gt;' Examples: | city | | Sacramento | | Sacramento | </code></pre> <p>Step Definition file -</p> <pre><code>And 'I live in {string} City' do |city| city &amp;lt;&amp;lt; ' City' puts "#{city}" end And /^I am not from '(.+)'$/ do |city| city &amp;lt;&amp;lt; ' city' puts "#{city}" end </code></pre> <p>gemfile -</p> <pre><code>source 'https://rubygems.org' gem 'cucumber', '~&amp;gt; 6.1.0' </code></pre> <p><strong>Expected behavior</strong><br /> Should be<br /> loop 1</p> <pre><code>I live in Sacramento City I am not from Sacramento city </code></pre> <p>loop 2</p> <pre><code>I live in Sacramento City I am not from Sacramento city </code></pre> <p><strong>Context &amp; Motivation</strong><br /> This fails Cucumber feature plans in our automation suite. To fix it right now we are updating <code>&amp;lt;&amp;lt;</code> with <code>+=</code> but would be great to have <code>&amp;lt;&amp;lt;</code> working to append strings.</p> <p><strong>Screenshots</strong><br /> <a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9060416/122450987-8594e280-cf5c-11eb-8c95-324e254d19f5.png">image</a></p> <p><strong>Your Environment</strong></p> <p>• Versions used: Cucumber 6.1.0 and Ruby 2.6.4 • Operating System and version: Windows 10 64bit</p> <p><strong>Additional context</strong><br /> When Cucumber is downgraded to 6.0.0 <code>&amp;lt;&amp;lt;</code> does not clone/append strings and works fine<br /> When I use Cucumber Expressions in step definition I can't reproduce the issue it's only when I use regular expression.<br /> And when table values are not same this issue cannot be reproduced</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-06-17 12:05:04

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1553

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1553#issuecomment-863492527|Comment on #1553 Scenario outline Table Value is Getting Cloned on Each Run>
This feels related to <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1532">#1532</a>, but I might be wrong. IMO either we need to freeze the argument (so you get an error trying to call `&lt;&lt;` on it) or we need to copy it for each step match.

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1362

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1362#issuecomment-864404083|Comment on #1362 Deprecate "calling steps from step definitions" functionality>
<p>&gt; Why do the existing steps need to be re-written?</p> <p>Because using this method, the <code>within</code> is defined (duplicatively!) in each step that uses it, rather than as a generically applicable modifier. That means that every time I want to use a new step with <code>within</code>, I have to rewrite its step definition.</p> <p>Contrast this with what I currently do, where I write the <code>within</code> modifier once and it is then applicable to <em>any</em> existing step, without further rewriting the step definitions.</p> <p>Does that answer your question? Do you need this explained further?</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-06-21 09:56:10

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1362

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1362#issuecomment-865193610|Comment on #1362 Deprecate "calling steps from step definitions" functionality>
<p>I hear ya <a href="https://github.com/marnen">@marnen</a>.</p> <p>The thing we're trying to avoid is where people try and evaluate Gherkin at runtime, like:</p> <pre><code>step("I am logged in as #{username}") </code></pre> <p>Instead of just extracting/calling a helper method:</p> <pre><code>login_as username </code></pre> <p>But I can see how you've made use of this feature to give you something powerful.</p> <p>I wonder if we could do something that helped us to avoid the dynamic runtime Gherkin evaluation we're trying to avoid, but still have you this kind of functionality, something like:</p> <pre><code>Suffix("within {string}") do |selector, &amp;amp;step| within(selector || 'html', &amp;amp;step) end </code></pre> <p>That new <code>Suffix</code> DSL method would effectively create a new, suffixed step definition for every existing step definition, wrapping the original one.</p> <p>WDYT?</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-06-21 21:28:33

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Issue opened by BoWunder

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1556|#1556 Not all results are shown in the Run-window, even as I follow the tutorial>
<p>So I have recently started my journey with Cucumber and Ruby. To get started, I have used the tutorial on <a href="http://guru99.com">guru99.com</a> (<a href="https://www.guru99.com/cucumber-tutorials.html">https://www.guru99.com/cucumber-tutorials.html</a>). I am aware that the tutorial is for an older version, but I would still expect the same results to be shown in the Run-window.</p> <p><strong>The Issue:</strong><br /> Based on the tutorial, I would expect to see three results; the results of the multiplication, the number scenario 'passed'/'failed', and the number of steps 'passed'/'failed'. Instead, I only get the result of the multiplication. I do not see the number of 'passed'/'failed' 'Scenario'/'Steps' anywhere.</p> <p><strong>To Reproduce</strong><br /> Steps to reproduce the behavior:</p> <ol><li>Go to '<a href="https://www.guru99.com/cucumber-installation.html">https://www.guru99.com/cucumber-installation.html</a>'</li><li>Scroll down to 'First Cucumber Script' and follow the tutorial.</li><li>Follow instructions to script 'CucumberFirstProject', with feature list and step definition.</li><li>Once scripted, Run multiplication.feature</li><li>Observe the error in the Run-window (the lack of 'Scenario' and 'Steps' as seen in the "Actual Result" screenshot).</li> </ol> <p><strong>Expected behavior</strong><br /> Run-window shows three results: The multiplication result, the number of Scenarios passed or failed, and the number fo steps passed or failed. (See the "Expected Result" screenshot taken from the tutorial)</p> <p><strong>Context &amp; Motivation</strong><br /> As someone new to Cucumber, I rely heavily on the tutorials. Sadly, tutorials does not explain mistakes you've made, issues you can't identify, or changes between versions.</p> <p><strong>Screenshots</strong><br /> If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.</p> <p><strong>Your Environment</strong></p> <p>• Versions used [2021.1.2] • Operating System and version [Windows 10 Pro]</p> <p><strong>Additional context</strong><br /> N/A<br /> <a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/86303765/122934197-9c2da600-d36f-11eb-9a71-83ad78e8810c.PNG">Expected result</a><br /> <a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/86303765/122934219-a2238700-d36f-11eb-92d2-1304de72a431.PNG">Actual Result</a></p>

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1556

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1556#issuecomment-865993294|Comment on #1556 Not all results are shown in the Run-window, even as I follow the tutorial>
<p>This is due to the Teamcity RubyMine formatter, it's nothing to do with either the code, cucumber or possibly even the tutorial site you are using.</p> <p>We have a 10 minute tutorial for cucumber available on our docs here: <a href="https://docs.cucumber.io/docs/guides/10-minute-tutorial/">https://docs.cucumber.io/docs/guides/10-minute-tutorial/</a></p> <p>The issue is the default formatter for RubyMine has changed now. If you just run that scenario from the CLI you will get the output you are looking for</p>

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] mattwynne approved aurelien-reeves's pull request

Review on #1542 Improvement of welcoming documentation
<p>My overall thoughts about this change are:</p> <ol><li>It makes things a lot better, and we should merge it ASAP</li><li>The contributing file is still very long, and I wonder if we can push some of the details off into other files in the /docs folder to keep it more concise and therefore approachable.</li><li>The example in the README (features/rule.feature) is a bit contrived / self-referential and might not do a great job of illustrating how to use Cucumber. I wonder if we should just link to the <a href="https://cucumber.io/docs/guides/10-minute-tutorial/">https://cucumber.io/docs/guides/10-minute-tutorial/</a> instead</li> </ol> <p>In any case, I'd merge this and we can iterate from there.</p> <p>I'd really love to do some user testing and get feedback from real users of this stuff.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-06-23 12:01:29

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Pull request merged by mattwynne

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1542|#1542 Improvement of welcoming documentation>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-06-24 01:16:11

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1542

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1542#issuecomment-867437964|Comment on #1542 Improvement of welcoming documentation>
<p>&gt; <code> &amp;gt; 2. The contributing file is still very long, and I wonder if we can push some of the details off into other files in the /docs folder to keep it more concise and therefore approachable. &amp;gt; &amp;gt;</code></p> <p>Yeah, I agree.<br /> I still like the approach of nextcloud. Their main "how to contribute" page is hosted on their website: <a href="https://nextcloud.com/contribute/">https://nextcloud.com/contribute/</a><br /> That would free the CONTRIBUTING.md in the repo from anything else than contribution dedicated to the code.</p> <p>&gt; <code> &amp;gt; 3. The example in the README (features/rule.feature) is a bit contrived / self-referential and might not do a great job of illustrating how to use Cucumber. I wonder if we should just link to the &lt;https://cucumber.io/docs/guides/10-minute-tutorial/&gt; instead &amp;gt; &amp;gt;</code></p> <p>The purpose of that example in the readme is to show a minimal example to show that cucumber is properly installed and running. The minimal reproducible example of it being working 😅</p> <p>It is not an illustration of how to use Cucumber.</p> <p>For illustrating how to use Cucumber, the section after that is redirecting to the documentation itself.</p> <p>&gt; I'd really love to do some user testing and get feedback from real users of this stuff.</p> <p>+1</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-06-24 01:24:51

<p>Yes it is.<br /> But it is also really frustrating to have the CI failing because of rubocop.</p> <p>This is a way to warn the developer before it happened.</p>

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/issues/514#issuecomment-868330088|Comment on #514 Bug on 2.3.0 and MacOS BigSur message formatter not found>
<p>This is the last line executed in Cucumber (from the stack trace above):</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/612b07b7e668f9631bd072d611a1265ec7993762/lib/cucumber/runtime.rb#L206">https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/612b07b7e668f9631bd072d611a1265ec7993762/lib/cucumber/runtime.rb#L206</a></p> <p>From there it seems to go into some kind of Rails monkey patching for constructors.</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/cb0a558f42fc6957fac4d2daa16771b72ff7da6e/activerecord/lib/active_record/inheritance.rb#L66">https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/cb0a558f42fc6957fac4d2daa16771b72ff7da6e/activerecord/lib/active_record/inheritance.rb#L66</a></p> <p>I'm not sure how or why one Cucumber's own classes has extended the <code>ActiveRecord::Inheritance::ClassMethods</code> module. I think understanding this could help fix this bug.</p>

2021-06-30 06:56:12

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Issue opened by BoWunder

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1557|#1557 Suggestions to making the "10 minute tutorials" more user/reader friendly>
<p>The "10 min tutorials" on <a href="https://docs.cucumber.io/docs/guides/10-minute-tutorial/">https://docs.cucumber.io/docs/guides/10-minute-tutorial/</a> are frustrating to use. It presume much from the readers when it suddenly swift between Command-promt windows and Ruby etc. between steps. It presumes that that the reader would understand "Gemfile", let alone how to use them.</p> <p>This may be enough information for someone who already know Ruby and Cucumber from the get-go (which would make a tutorial unnecessary by definition), but when you're a new user who only know "enough" to get around, but not to get into every crevasse, then it's a frustrating experience. It feels at times as if you get talk down to for them not knowing what the tutorial, by definition, should have been able to tell me in the first place.</p> <p><strong>Describe the solution you'd like</strong><br /> Images/Screenshots that shows when and where you are at any given point. To show where you as a reader are when the tutorial-text jump around in the menu. To show which window/command window etc. you're currently in at any given moment.</p> <p>Describe alternatives you've considered<br /> Bulleting, that clearly states the How and Where to do the how.</p> <p>Additional context<br /> (See image for reference).<br /> That is just an example of the "installing process". There are plenty more in the text, but for this example, you can see the attatched screenshot for reference.</p> <p>1: It start with "We’ll start by creating a new directory and an empty Ruby project." (In the same project or as two separate entities? Is the directory specific to the project or a new default? Should the directory be called something specific (like Gemfile) or is that optional?)</p> <p>Then it goes down to "Create a Gemfile with the following content:" - As a new user and as a ready, the question on ones mind is "Where?" In the directory? In the project file itself? In a new place? Should the Gemfile be given a specific filetype? (like Gemfile.rb?) Should the reader just write-in the versions as they are presented on the sire (Screenshot), or should they use the command-promt to find the right versions? (cucumber -version or other similar?). Does it matter?</p> <p>Thirdly, we get to "Install Cucumber and prepare the file structure:" - Again, is that in Ruby or in command promt? Is the reader still in the Gemfile? Should this be added at the start of a new [File].feature?</p> <p>I hope that this shows the issue I personally have had as a new user. The tutorial jump left and right with little explanation or consideration to anyone who supposedly not already possesses enough knowledge to make a tutorial void in the first place. It is called a "10 minutes tutorial", but personally, I have yet to reach the end of the tutorial. This is frustrating, partly due to the aforementioned "jumps", but also when you do manage to follow the tutorial, since when you come across an issue that halt one process, then you don't know why. This is especially an issue when it comes to writing an issue-report or asking for help, because you cannot be sure that you installed things right in the first place.</p> <p><a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/86303765/123971315-38802a00-d9ba-11eb-8c5e-0ece0b201caf.PNG">text ex</a></p>
Labels
🍼 incomplete, 📖 documentation

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>

Are you a developer? A tester? Anything else? • Why are you looking into cucumber-ruby? Are you looking for a testing tool for some ruby development? Or something else? For a new project or an existing one? • Are you familiar with other development languages like JavaScript or Java? • For reference and inspiration, do you know a tutorial of that kind - for any other tool, whatever it is - that you find easier to get into?</p>

2021-07-01 00:16:48

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1557

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1557#issuecomment-871990524|Comment on #1557 Suggestions to making the "10 minute tutorials" more user/reader friendly>
<p>Thanks for your reply.</p> <p>The 10 minutes tutorials are actually targeting an audience already familiar with the selected development environment - here: ruby.</p> <p>We may explicitly say so at the beginning of the tutorials.</p> <p>Cucumber remains a tool which requires some basic development skills, or the support from your development team.</p> <p>You may not need to be a professional developer, but with Ruby for example, knowing how to create a new Ruby project with a Gemfile is a prerequisite to going further with Cucumber. And it is the same with all Cucumber implementation.</p> <p>Also, it is not mandatory, but it would be far more easier to select an implementation of cucumber that match the project your want to test. For example, if the project under test is a ruby application, cucumber-ruby will fit perfectly. If your project is a javascript project, cucumber-js will be a better option.</p> <p>Last but not least: did you take a look at <a href="https://school.cucumber.io/collections">Cucumber School courses</a>? Maybe you'll find those more comfortable to follow than the 10 minutes tutorials</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-01 01:17:47

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1557

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1557#issuecomment-872157463|Comment on #1557 Suggestions to making the "10 minute tutorials" more user/reader friendly>
<p>I think we should state at the top of the tutorial that some prior knowledge is required:</p> <p>• Basic understanding of the Ruby programming language • Basic understanding of the Bundler tool and <code>Gemfile</code> • Some experience using a terminal • Some experience using a text editor</p> <p>It's beyond the scope of the Cucumber docs to teach readers these things, but we can link to some resources we recommend.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>

<p>In order to use cucumber (in whatever flavour you desire), it is definitely beneficial that you have a basic understanding of how that language structures its projects. I would recommend that for whatever language you are using, you undertake a basic course / read some books / online resources to get familiar with "how" it works.</p>

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Issue opened by BoWunder

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1558|#1558 Formulation of steps is seen as an irregularity? [Ruby]>
<p><strong>Describe the bug</strong><br /> Not sure if this is a bug or I have misunderstood details in Gherkin, but I have now twice experienced, that the formulation of my steps have been seen as "failed" - not due to the code itself, but to the wording of the "Given", "When", and "Then".</p> <p><strong>To Reproduce</strong><br /> There are no actual steps I can refer to, to replicate these happenings. Best I can do is to refer to the examples below and the provided material.</p> <p>Considering that Cucumber is supposed to allow a more free formulation of steps, then this seems odd.</p> <p>For example, "When I ask whether it's Friday yet" is seen as an error, while "When I ask if it is Friday yet" is seen as correct (see the blue markings in images "Cucumber Grammatics 01" and "Cucumber Grammatics 02").</p> <p>Another Example is how "Then I should be told the answer" is seen as wrong, while "Then I should get the answer" is seen as correct" (see the yellow markings in images "Cucumber Grammatics 02" and "Cucumber Grammatics 03").</p> <p><strong>Expected behavior</strong></p> <p>I would expect that the wording used for the steps would be of little important (not counting the actual coding in the _step.rb file). It is clear that Cucumber (or maybe Ruby?) does not recognize certain words or formulations of a sentence. That is quite an issue, as I would then suspect that the use of certain slang / business-related terms would/could produce a similar false-negative.</p> <p><strong>Context &amp; Motivation</strong></p> <p>Context is the worry, that the use of client-specific terms, business-lingo or wordings would cause false-negatives.</p> <p><strong>Screenshots</strong><br /> <a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/86303765/124445380-c9bb1c00-dd7f-11eb-8d84-5a5c3aa1cf17.PNG">Cucumber Grammatics 01</a><br /> <a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/86303765/124445382-ca53b280-dd7f-11eb-97cc-18c7629455ac.PNG">Cucumber Grammatics 02</a><br /> <a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/86303765/124445386-caec4900-dd7f-11eb-89bf-bfef522d6517.PNG">Cucumber Grammatics 03</a></p> <p><strong>Your Environment</strong></p> <p>• Versions used [Ruby30-x64] • Operating System and version: [Windows 10 Pro] • Build tool: [Rubymine 2021.1.2.]</p> <p><strong>Additional context</strong><br /> Posting Code Here (fixed and non-fixed)</p> <h4>[Feature File (non-fixed)]:</h4> <p>Feature: is it Friday yet?<br /> Everybody wants to know when it's Friday</p> <p>Scenario: Sunday is or is not Friday<br /> Given today is maybe Friday<br /> When I ask whether it's Friday yet<br /> Then I should be told the answer</p> <h4>[Feature File (fixed)]:</h4> <p>Feature: is it Friday yet?<br /> Everybody wants to know when it's Friday</p> <p>Scenario: Sunday is or is not Friday<br /> Given today is maybe Friday<br /> When I ask if it is Friday yet<br /> Then I should get the answer</p> <h4>[_step.rb (non-fixed)]</h4> <p>Given(/^today is maybe Friday$/) do #|current<em>day|<br /> current</em>day = Date.today.friday?<br /> if current_day == 1<br /> <a href="https://github.com/Ans">@Ans</a> = "Yes!"<br /> <a href="https://github.com/today">@today</a> = "Friday"<br /> else<br /> <a href="https://github.com/Ans">@Ans</a> = "Nope..."<br /> <a href="https://github.com/today">@today</a> = "not Friday"<br /> end<br /> end</p> <p>When(/^I ask whether it's Friday yet$/) do<br /> puts "Is it Friday today?"<br /> end</p> <p>Then(/^I should be told the answer$/) do #|answer|<br /> puts "Today is #{<a href="https://github.com/today">@today</a>}."<br /> puts "So in short; #{<a href="https://github.com/Ans">@Ans</a>}"<br /> end</p> <h4>[_step.rb (fixed)]</h4> <p>Given(/^today is maybe Friday$/) do #|current<em>day|<br /> current</em>day = Date.today.friday?<br /> if current_day == 1<br /> <a href="https://github.com/Ans">@Ans</a> = "Yes!"<br /> <a href="https://github.com/today">@today</a> = "Friday"<br /> else<br /> <a href="https://github.com/Ans">@Ans</a> = "Nope..."<br /> <a href="https://github.com/today">@today</a> = "not Friday"<br /> end<br /> end</p> <p>When(/^I ask if it is Friday yet$/) do<br /> puts "Is it Friday today?"<br /> end</p> <p>Then(/^I should get the answer$/) do #|answer|<br /> puts "Today is #{<a href="https://github.com/today">@today</a>}."<br /> puts "So in short; #{<a href="https://github.com/Ans">@Ans</a>}"<br /> end</p>

🍼 incomplete
Comments
1
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-05 02:19:08

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1558

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1558#issuecomment-873952760|Comment on #1558 Formulation of steps is seen as an irregularity? [Ruby]>
<p>&gt; Considering that Cucumber is supposed to allow a more free formulation of steps, then this seems odd.</p> <p>Yes, Cucumber can allow a more free formulation of steps, but this remain a software. There is no magic behind it. Some development still has to be made as part of the automation process to tell Cucumber how to recognize steps. Cucumber uses <a href="https://cucumber.io/docs/cucumber/cucumber-expressions/">cucumber expressions</a> to match steps with actual code.</p> <p>For the errors you encountered, from what I can see, Cucumber actually does not have issue recognizing your steps. It seems you have some code duplication in <code>IsItFriday_step.rb</code> and <code>whenfriday_step.rb</code>. Cucumber found two possible ways to execute your step and cannot decide which one to use.</p> <p>As suggested, you could execute cucumber with <code>--guess</code> to make it pick one way. But it would be better to actually remove the duplication.</p> <p>I guess it has been fixed later because you may have update your formulation, and one of the two steps in the code, so that removed the duplication.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-05 11:45:51

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1558

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1558#issuecomment-874278852|Comment on #1558 Formulation of steps is seen as an irregularity? [Ruby]>
<p><a href="https://github.com/BoWunder">@BoWunder</a> does this make sense now? The "Ambiguous match" error is caused by you having multiple definitions for the same step. It's nothing to do with how you've worded it.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-05 11:46:52

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1558

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1558#issuecomment-874279147|Comment on #1558 Formulation of steps is seen as an irregularity? [Ruby]>
<p><a href="https://github.com/BoWunder">@BoWunder</a> does this make sense now? The "Ambiguous match" error is caused by you having multiple definitions for the same step. It's nothing to do with how you've worded it.</p> <p>By the way, if you're new to Cucumber you might want to check out the free video course: <a href="https://school.cucumber.io/courses/bdd-with-cucumber-ruby">https://school.cucumber.io/courses/bdd-with-cucumber-ruby</a></p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>

A Ruby runtime environment should behave the same on any platform, no?</p> <p>That would be a bug in the Ruby runtime environment 😅</p> <p>Here as <a href="https://github.com/tclaus">@tclaus</a> and <a href="https://github.com/aslakhellesoy">@aslakhellesoy</a> have already noticed, it seems to relate on <a href="https://github.com/tclaus">@tclaus</a> project if I understood well.</p>

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1559

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1559#issuecomment-875479039|Comment on #1559 Update cucumber-html-reporter dependency to 15.0>

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Issue opened by BoWunder

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1560|#1560 Cucumber School example: cannot make code working>
<p><strong>Describe the bug</strong><br /> So currently, I'm going through the Cucumber school for Ruby,. I've done the change to make Sean "just" shout ( at 1:40 and onward; <a href="https://school.cucumber.io/courses/take/bdd-with-cucumber-ruby/lessons/15974202-incidental-details">https://school.cucumber.io/courses/take/bdd-with-cucumber-ruby/lessons/15974202-incidental-details</a> ). Running the code via command promt does now yeld the same results as in the video, and i do not know why (This is what I see when I run the code <a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/86303765/124885197-4e51a880-dfd3-11eb-9004-f99a4862e1dd.png">image</a> )</p> <p>For additional details, I've gone through the course material (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber/tree/main/content/05/code/ruby/05-location-specified-in-data-table">https://github.com/cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber/tree/main/content/05/code/ruby/05-location-specified-in-data-table</a>), and with the exception of the spec-files (which I did not add to my project, since that caused issues that made the code unable to run), everything is as seen in the course material.</p> <p>From what little I can gather, the "issue" supposedly is that "shout" is undefined, even through I got: it written as shown inboth the video and in the course material:<br /> (step_definition)<br /> When("Sean shouts") do<br /> <a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a>['Sean'].shout("Hello, world")<br /> end</p> <p>Here's the code. Mind that I it may be a little different as i continued with the sessions in the hope, that a solution would present itself.:</p> <p>//////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////<br /> <strong>Feature-file: hear_shout.feature</strong><br /> Feature: Hear shout</p> <p>Shouty allows users to "hear" other users "shouts" as long as they are close enough to each other.</p> <p>Rule: Shouts can be heard by other users</p> <pre><code>Scenario: Listener hears a message Given a person named Sean And a person named Lucy When Sean shouts "Free bagels at Sean's" Then Lucy should hear Sean's message </code></pre> <p>Rule: Shouts should only be heard if listener is within range</p> <pre><code>Scenario: Listener is within range Given the range is 100 And people are located at | name | Sean | Lucy | | location | 0 | 50 | When Sean shouts Then Lucy should hear a shout Scenario: Listener is out of range Given the range is 100 And people are located at | name | Sean | Larry | | location | 0 | 150 | When Sean shouts Then Larry should not hear a shout </code></pre> <p>Rule: Listener should be able to hear multiple shouts</p> <pre><code>Scenario: Two shouts Given a person named Sean And a person named Lucy When Sean shouts "Free bagels!" And Sean shouts "Free toast!" Then Lucy hears the following messages: | Free bagels! | | Free toast! | </code></pre> <p>Rule: Maximum length of message is 180 characters</p> <p>//////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////<br /> <strong>Step Definitions: step_definition.rb</strong><br /> require "shouty"</p> <p>DEFAULT_RANGE = 100</p> <p>Before do<br /> <a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a> = {}<br /> @network = Shouty::Network.new(DEFAULT_RANGE)<br /> end</p> <p>Given("the range is {int}") do |range|<br /> @network = Shouty::Network.new(range)<br /> end</p> <p>Given("a person named {word}") do |name|<br /> <a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a>[name] = Shouty::Person.new(@network, 0)<br /> end</p> <p>Given("people are located at") do |table|<br /> p table.transpose.symbolic<em>hashes.each do |name: , location: |<br /> <a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a>[name] = Shouty::Person.new(@network, location.to</em>i)<br /> end<br /> end</p> <p>When("Sean shouts") do<br /> <a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a>['Sean'].shout("Hello, world")<br /> end</p> <p>When("Sean shouts {string}") do |message|<br /> <a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a>['Sean'].shout(message)<br /> @message<em>from</em>sean = message<br /> end</p> <p>Then("Lucy should hear a shout") do<br /> expect(<a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a>['Lucy'].messages_heard.count).to eq(1)<br /> end</p> <p>Then("Lucy should hear Sean's message") do<br /> expect(<a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a>['Lucy'].messages<em>heard).to eq [@message</em>from_sean]<br /> end</p> <p>Then("Larry should not hear a shout") do<br /> expect(<a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a>['Larry'].messages_heard.count).to eq(0)<br /> end</p> <p>Then "Larry should not hear Sean's message" do<br /> expect(<a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a>['Larry'].messages<em>heard).not</em>to include(@message<em>from</em>sean)<br /> end</p> <p>Then("Lucy hears the following messages:") do |expected<em>messages|<br /> actual</em>messages = <a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a>['Lucy'].messages_heard.map { |message| [message] }</p> <p>expected<em>messages.diff!(actual</em>messages)<br /> end</p> <p>//////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////<br /> <strong>(lib): shouty.rb</strong><br /> module Shouty<br /> class Person<br /> attr<em>reader :messages</em>heard, :location</p> <pre><code>def initialize(network, location) @messages_heard = [] @network = network @location = location @network.subscribe(self) end def shout(message) @network.broadcast(message, @location)#; end def hear(message) @messages_heard &amp;lt;&amp;lt; message end </code></pre> <p>end</p> <p>class Network<br /> def initialize(range)<br /> <a href="https://github.com/range">@range</a> = range<br /> <a href="https://github.com/listeners">@listeners</a> = []<br /> end</p> <pre><code>def subscribe(person) @listeners &amp;lt;&amp;lt; person end def broadcast(message, shouter_location) @listeners.each do |listener| if (listener.location - shouter_location).abs &amp;lt;= @range listener.hear(message) end end end </code></pre> <p>end<br /> end</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-08 02:46:40

<p>Keep in mind that I'm still very new to ruby, so what you just said blew largely over my head. However, as you can see in the code above:</p> <p>from step_definition, we have;</p> <p><strong><a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a> = {}</strong></p> <p>And it does contain Sean for the specific line of code;</p> <p><strong>When("Sean shouts") do<br /> <a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a>['Sean'].shout("Hello, world")<br /> end</strong></p>

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1560

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1560#issuecomment-876961929|Comment on #1560 Cucumber School example: cannot make code working>
<p>Did you consider studying Ruby and learning some basic in development before going deeper with Cucumber?</p> <p>Even if cucumber and cucumber school both try to be as easy as possible, some basic development knowledge is a requirement. Cucumber remains an automation tool.</p> <p>The formulation part - writing feature files - does not required any skill and some collaboration tools like Cucumber Studio may even make that part easier.</p> <p>However the automation part - writing the code, the step definitions, which will execute the tests - remain a task that required some development knowledge.</p> <p>You seem very interested into Cucumber, and that is great! You just need to get a step back and take a little time to be ready first. Once you have the basic understanding which are required - some very basic understanding of ruby development - it will be far easier for you.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-09 00:42:54

<p>From what I can understand, <a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a> is not the issue. Like it says in the first image, it considers "shout" to be undefined. The lines of code it reacts to, as far as I can tell, are:</p> <p><strong>When("Sean shouts") do<br /> <a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a>['Sean'].shout("Hello, world")<br /> end</strong></p> <p>The only thing I can think of is that it won't read "Hello, world", because it's not an actual message? (compared to another shout:)<br /> <strong>When("Sean shouts {string}") do |message|<br /> <a href="https://github.com/people">@people</a>['Sean'].shout(message)<br /> @message<em>from</em>sean = message<br /> end</strong></p> <p>But that's the tutorial for that specific scenario; Sean does not need to say anything specific, we're just checking if Lura and Larry are within range or not.</p> <p>So, yeah, the definition of "shout" should be the issue somehow?</p>

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Pull request merged by luke-hill

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1549|#1549 Update rule feature to test using tags>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-09 06:41:19

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1551

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1551#issuecomment-877198367|Comment on #1551 Cucumber "Transform" replacment, ParameterType, does not work for all use-cases, espeically Tables>
<p>So in essence the issue here is that we cannot use the cukeexp parameter type because the capture is done anonymously (i.e. a <code>{}</code> is not provided because it's a data table).</p> <p>Instead of trying to make a fit b, why don't we come at this from a different way <a href="https://github.com/mattwynne">@mattwynne</a></p> <p>Why don't we make the table "methods" and manipulability bits function outside, maybe through including a helper or setting a config option? Although they already are by default available in the cucumber world, so actually this point is redundant!</p> <p>Also whilst I haven't tried it. In theory could you not capture the data table using a regex that included new lines (I appreciate that's not pretty)</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-09 10:48:54

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1551

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1551#issuecomment-877354709|Comment on #1551 Cucumber "Transform" replacment, ParameterType, does not work for all use-cases, espeically Tables>
<p><a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a> yes, I think that's the essence of the problem.</p> <p>I was just suggesting a workaround for the OP, given the way things are.</p> <p>I'm sure we could add something, either as a standalone helper, or something in the DSL (e.g. <code>TransformDataTables</code>) or as methods on the <code>DataTable</code> instances, to help people do this. We need to understand a bit more about the use-cases, I think.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-09 23:09:29

[cucumber/cucumber-rails] Pull request opened by DanielVartanov

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/518|#518 Remove mentions of the disused `spork` gem>
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>Remove mentioned of the disused <code>spork</code> gem.</p> <p><strong>Motivation and Context</strong></p> <p><a href="https://github.com/sporkrb/spork">spork gem</a> is now disused, it makes no sense to mention it while running <code>rails generate cucumber:install --help</code> and to act upon it.</p> <p><strong>Types of changes</strong></p> <p>☑︎ Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue). ☐ New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality). ☐ Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected).</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☐ I've added tests for my code. ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub Actions: test (3.0, rails_6_1) (https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/runs/3035292967)

2021-07-12 00:13:36

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1561

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1561#issuecomment-878032141|Comment on #1561 Suppress unnecessary warnings about ANSICON in integrated terminal of vscode>
<p>Thanks for your PR!</p> <p>Myself - as Windows 10 now supports AINSI colors for the terminal - I would be in favor of totally remove that auto-discovery attempt of coloring support for Windows and to keep colors enabled per default.</p> <p>I did some tests myself, and colors are working well without ANSICON on vscode, on the new Windows Terminal, using powershell, and even on the old legacy cmd.exe.</p> <p>For older version of Windows, I would instead document the fact that colors may be unsupported and that user should turn them off themselves using the <code>--no-color</code> flag, or install and use ANSICON on their own.</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/orgs/cucumber/teams/cucumber-ruby">@cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a> what do you think?</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-12 02:34:11

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1561

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1561#issuecomment-878125760|Comment on #1561 Suppress unnecessary warnings about ANSICON in integrated terminal of vscode>
<p><a href="https://github.com/yosukei3108">@yosukei3108</a> would you feel confident in:</p> <p>• removing the <code>if windows</code> block in <code>ainsicolor.rb</code> • updating the changelog explaining that support for automatic detection of ansicon on Windows has been removed • creating a new document in <code>docs</code> explaining to legacy windows users that coloring may be broken, that they may need to use <code>--no-color</code> flag, or to install ANSICON (with a link to the ansicon repo)?</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-12 04:27:24

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1561

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1561#issuecomment-878235675|Comment on #1561 Suppress unnecessary warnings about ANSICON in integrated terminal of vscode>
<p>&gt; Your kind hints would help me. I'll do my best!</p> <p>:)</p> <p>So to begin with, I guess we could simply remove the following block of code from <code>ansicolor.rb</code></p> <pre><code>if Cucumber::WINDOWS_MRI unless ENV['ANSICON'] || ENV['TERM_PROGRAM'] == 'vscode' STDERR.puts %{****** WARNING: You must use ANSICON 1.31 or higher (&lt;https://github.com/adoxa/ansicon/&gt;) to get coloured output on Windows} Cucumber::Term::ANSIColor.coloring = false end end </code></pre> <p>Make sure tu execute <code>bundle exec rake</code> to execute all the tests, but I think it should be alright.</p> <p>Then in the CHANGELOG.md, we should add an entry in the <code>In Git &amp;gt; removed</code> paragraph to tell that on Windows, support for ANSICON has been removed due to recent version of Windows properly supporting ansi colors in the terminal, with a note inviting users to fallback on using <code>--no-color</code> or installing ANSICON globally if needed (with a link to <a href="https://github.com/adoxa/ansicon/">https://github.com/adoxa/ansicon/</a>).</p> <p>Actually I guess that this will be enough for now as the info will be at the top of the changelog.<br /> If we notice that some user are asking about that, we may have a dedicated doc, but for now it won't be necessary.</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/yosukei3108">@yosukei3108</a> does that sounds good?</p>

2021-07-12 11:29:53

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1551

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1551#issuecomment-878499491|Comment on #1551 Cucumber "Transform" replacment, ParameterType, does not work for all use-cases, espeically Tables>
<p>The primary use-case we are using it for is to allow variables to be set in the feature itself, which is replaced by the code to an actual value. For example:</p> <p>Replace the string "auto<em>RANDOMALPHANUMERIC</em>5" with something like "auto<em>ABC4321</em>5". Or some other variable, doesn't have to just be random data.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-12 12:29:11

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1551

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1551#issuecomment-878536867|Comment on #1551 Cucumber "Transform" replacment, ParameterType, does not work for all use-cases, espeically Tables>
<p><a href="https://github.com/mattwynne">@mattwynne</a><br /> The general case, turning a table into any other arbitrary object is useful. If an object is used in multiple step definitions it avoids the need to do so in each step.</p> <p>The common/datatable module has several examples.</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a></p> <p>Because ruby lacks types you'll need a way in the step definition to select which table transform should be used. Something like:</p> <pre><code>Given /a step that takes a table:/, expand_place_holders do |table| ... # do stuff with the expanded table data end </code></pre> <p>Dunno if that works for ruby. In this case <code>expand_place_holders</code> is a function that processes the table and has access to the world context.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-12 13:12:27

<p>I'm closing this since it's not about a bug in cucumber-ruby.</p>

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1432

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1432#issuecomment-884029346|Comment on #1432 Cucumber4: Obtain Cucumber 3 scenario properties in hooks.rb>
<p>It appears that the patch by <a href="https://github.com/thedeeno">@thedeeno</a> no longer works with cucumber 7.0.0. Investigating further, but if anyone already found the solution I'd love to hear it :)</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-21 02:16:07

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1432

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1432#issuecomment-884030343|Comment on #1432 Cucumber4: Obtain Cucumber 3 scenario properties in hooks.rb>
<p>The internal structure of cucumber messages has basically been rewritten from scratch in cucumber 7. We now use a JSON schema instead of protobufs. Consequently, it's likely a lot of the internal structure has changed.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-21 02:24:53

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1432

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1432#issuecomment-884036725|Comment on #1432 Cucumber4: Obtain Cucumber 3 scenario properties in hooks.rb>
<p>This patch works for me:</p> <pre><code>module Cucumber module RunningTestCase class TestCase &amp;lt; SimpleDelegator def feature string = File.read(location.file) document = ::Gherkin::Parser.new.parse(string) document.feature end end end end </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-21 03:23:49

[cucumber/cucumber-rails] Comment on #518

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/518#issuecomment-884095380|Comment on #518 Remove mentions of the disused `spork` gem>
<p>Hi <a href="https://github.com/DanielVartanov">@DanielVartanov</a>,</p> <p>Thanks for your making your first contribution to Cucumber, and welcome to the Cucumber committers team! You can now push directly to this repo and all other repos under the cucumber organization! 🍾</p> <p>In return for this generous offer we hope you will:</p> <p>• ✅ Continue to use branches and pull requests. When someone on the core team approves a pull request (yours or someone else's), you're welcome to merge it yourself. • 💚 Commit to setting a good example by following and upholding our <a href="https://cucumber.io/conduct">code of conduct</a> in your interactions with other collaborators and users. • 💬 Join the <a href="http://cucumber.io/support#slack">community Slack channel</a> to meet the rest of the team and make yourself at home. • ℹ️ Don't feel obliged to help, just do what you can if you have the time and the energy. • 🙋 Ask if you need anything. We're looking for feedback about how to make the project more welcoming, so please tell us!</p> <p>On behalf of the Cucumber core team,<br /> Aslak Hellesøy<br /> Creator of Cucumber</p>

[cucumber/cucumber-rails] New release Release - v2.4.0 published by luke-hill

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/releases/tag/v2.4.0|Release - v2.4.0>
<p><strong>New Features</strong></p> <p>• Added new docker / Makefile script to permit releasing from repo • Permit up to cucumber v7 • Support Ruby 3</p> <p><strong>Changed</strong></p> <p>• Rubocop updates</p> <p><strong>Removed</strong></p> <p>• Removed traces of legacy spork setup / help (As they are no longer used)</p>

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1432

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1432#issuecomment-884756072|Comment on #1432 Cucumber4: Obtain Cucumber 3 scenario properties in hooks.rb>
<p>I put both "Bug" and "Enhancement" labels because historically, it is a regression when cucumber v4 has been released, but regarding all the internal rework which led to the actual v7, internally it would actually be an enhancement 😅</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-22 08:11:24

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1432

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1432#issuecomment-884992183|Comment on #1432 Cucumber4: Obtain Cucumber 3 scenario properties in hooks.rb>
<p>After our community meeting, it appears that this was actually not a regression, but an expected result from passing a <code>pickle</code> to the hook instead of the <code>AST</code>.</p> <p>Actually a fix to that issue would be to rename the parameter from <code>scenario</code> to <code>test_case</code>. That way it would reflect better the intent behind it.</p> <p>To the user who would need access to the data of the feature - like its name - in a hook, why would you do so? What are your use-cases? Your needs?</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-22 08:14:29

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1432

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1432#issuecomment-884994612|Comment on #1432 Cucumber4: Obtain Cucumber 3 scenario properties in hooks.rb>
<p>Thanks <a href="https://github.com/aurelien-reeves">@aurelien-reeves</a>! The feature name is used by VCR to name the cassettes of auto-recorded interactions with third parties. If there's a better way to do this I'm more than happy to change that, but I kind of like the VCR folders this way.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-22 09:05:59

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1432

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1432#issuecomment-885032746|Comment on #1432 Cucumber4: Obtain Cucumber 3 scenario properties in hooks.rb>
<p>You can still access the scenario name, the scenario location (Which includes a fully qualified filepath), and things like tags.</p> <p>The switchover in mentality (I was against it at first too), is that the pickles execute the test cases, i.e. they should be thought of as the top level wrapper (or a scenario if thats easier). The feature isn't a realistic wrapper at this point.</p> <p>I mentioned VCR were one of the larger consumers of this, I think maybe using a scenario name to qualify your VCR cassettes might help.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-22 09:19:23

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1432

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1432#issuecomment-885042378|Comment on #1432 Cucumber4: Obtain Cucumber 3 scenario properties in hooks.rb>
<p>Another use case is having a custom formatter that logs metadata such as relative feature location, id, name and scenario gherkin plus the pass and fail state to with error output and such to an elk instance. (Something we're planning to open source in the near future.)</p> <p>I'd expect other report tooling that hooks into things like zephyr scale or x-ray would benefit from a way to access this information. We're often more interested in the feature ast data in these situations though. I don't necessarily care about the form the data takes, Json is completely acceptable. We used to be able to resolve this through scenario.feature.source</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-22 11:42:52

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1432

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1432#issuecomment-885147967|Comment on #1432 Cucumber4: Obtain Cucumber 3 scenario properties in hooks.rb>
<p><a href="https://github.com/Castone22">@Castone22</a> the formatter / events API is a better fit for that, though it's probably not very well documented at the moment. There are examples in Cucumber's own codebase were we match together the data from the test case result and Gherkin AST events to give the kind of info you're looking for, e.g. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/97a03c0bd8199d5dcd3fc8de5993d01306dd4a1f/lib/cucumber/formatter/pretty.rb">https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/97a03c0bd8199d5dcd3fc8de5993d01306dd4a1f/lib/cucumber/formatter/pretty.rb</a></p> <p>It would be possible to build a richer domain model from these events to surface into a user API, but it's not something we have at the moment.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-22 11:47:31

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1432

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1432#issuecomment-885150749|Comment on #1432 Cucumber4: Obtain Cucumber 3 scenario properties in hooks.rb>
<p>Yes those is what I ultimately ended up using. A lack of a direct link from a test case to it's ast source was a little awkward at first though using an ast lookup was the pattern I was referring to, not the protobuf that resulted from using it back in 5. I was waiting for confirmation this was the intended route before I continued implementing against it though.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-22 11:52:38

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1432

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1432#issuecomment-885153793|Comment on #1432 Cucumber4: Obtain Cucumber 3 scenario properties in hooks.rb>
<p><a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">@brasmusson</a> really clarified it for me today at the Zoom community meeting, that the hooks are part of an <em>execution model</em>, and we should keep the info exposed in them lean because, for example, we might have test cases that were generated from sources other than Gherkin documents, or test cases running in parallel.</p> <p>On the other hand, the events API used by the formatters is the higher-level place where you can observe everything going on in the Cucumber run, including AST nodes <em>and</em> execution results.</p> <p>I think we're probably missing an abstraction layer that makes it easier to work with the events API for common use cases, so please keep talking to us and see if there are patterns in what you do with it that could be pushed upstream.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-22 23:44:54

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1432

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1432#issuecomment-885435335|Comment on #1432 Cucumber4: Obtain Cucumber 3 scenario properties in hooks.rb>
<p>Thanks for all those explanations everyone!</p> <p>What is that VCR project you are talking about?</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>

<p><a href="https://github.com/aurelien-reeves">@aurelien-reeves</a> <a href="https://github.com/vcr/vcr">https://github.com/vcr/vcr</a> it's quite a large gem used in lots of projects (Like rails testing for example).</p>

2021-07-26 00:23:15

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Issue opened by aurelien-reeves

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1563|#1563 Which are the supported platforms?>
<p>On the README, we announce that the supported platforms are:</p> <pre><code>- Ruby 3.0 - Ruby 2.7 - Ruby 2.6 - Ruby 2.5 - Ruby 2.4 - Ruby 2.3 - JRuby 9.2 (with some limitations) </code></pre> <p>But the CI actually checks only</p> <pre><code>- Ruby 3.0 - Ruby 2.7 - Ruby 2.6 - Ruby 2.5 - JRuby 9.2 (with some limitations) </code></pre> <p>So, do we support Ruby 2.3 and 2.4?</p> <p>If so, we should add those in the CI.<br /> If not, we should remove those from the README.</p> <p>Caution: some dependencies like Rubocop do not support anymore Ruby &lt;= 2.4 on Windows so such build won't work.</p>
Labels
🏦 debt, ❓ question
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-26 00:25:03

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1563

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1563#issuecomment-886448101|Comment on #1563 Which are the supported platforms?>
<p>Myself I think we should remove Ruby 2.3 and 2.4 from supported platforms</p> <p>Support for Ruby 2.4 itself has ended more than 1 year ago: <a href="https://www.ruby-lang.org/en/news/2020/04/05/support-of-ruby-2-4-has-ended/">https://www.ruby-lang.org/en/news/2020/04/05/support-of-ruby-2-4-has-ended/</a></p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-26 00:42:14

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1562

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1562#issuecomment-886562346|Comment on #1562 Remove dependency to cucumber-wire>
<p><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-wire/pull/46">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-wire#46</a> is the cucumber-ruby-wire counter-part of this PR.</p> <p>Everything seems to be ok actually, we would just need a deprecation/release plan for this but technically, it seems to be all good</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-07-26 21:01:57

2021-07-27 00:06:42

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1563

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1563#issuecomment-887266783|Comment on #1563 Which are the supported platforms?>
<p>I do not suggest to prevent cucumber-ruby from working with ruby 2.3 and 2.4.</p> <p>What about removing those Rubies from "supported platforms" list, and if issues are opened someday related to those version, we consider fixing those or not depending on the issues? As I said, those versions are already not part of the CI. That would not make a big difference.</p> <p>But at some point, explicitly keeping the compatibility with ruby 2.3 and 2.4 may sometime prevent cucumber to take some benefit from new features in more recent rubies</p> <p>But if we want to let those as part of the "supported platforms" list, we may consider bringing those back in the CI</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1564

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1564#issuecomment-888468894|Comment on #1564 Deprecate usage of built-in cucumber wire protocol>
<p>I think we can release the deprecation notice in a minor release, so 7.1 rather than 8.0. See the advice <a href="https://semver.org/#how-should-i-handle-deprecating-functionality">here</a> from the semver docs:</p> <p>&gt; Before you completely remove the functionality in a new major release there should be at least one <strong>minor</strong> release that contains the deprecation so that users can smoothly transition to the new API.</p> <p>(emphasis mine)</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>

You can also add some checks if you want to.</p> <p>☑︎ New and existing tests are passing locally and on CI ☑︎ <code>bundle exec rubocop</code> reports no offenses</p>

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Pull request opened by aurelien-reeves

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1565|#1565 Move CI to GitHub actions>
<p><strong>Description</strong></p> <p>Moving the CI from Circle CI to Gihub actions.</p> <p>Regular (ubuntu) builds: ✔️<br /> Windows builds: ✔️<br /> JRuby build: ✔️<br /> 🆕 MacOS builds 🆕: ✔️</p> <p>The previous GitHub workflow was designed to push to cucumber reports, but it did not worked anymore since personal tokens have been deprecated on reports. It has been removed, we may consider recreating a dedicated workflow for that purpose if we want to, with a new collection token.</p> <p>If we want to activate back the CCK tests, we could created a dedicated workflow too</p> <p><strong>Type of change</strong></p> <p>Please delete options that are not relevant.</p> <p>• Refactoring (improvements to code design or tooling that don't change behaviour)</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>Your PR is ready for review once the following checklist is<br /> complete. You can also add some checks if you want to.</p> <p>☐ New and existing tests are passing locally and on CI ☐ <code>bundle exec rubocop</code> reports no offenses</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub Actions: test (jruby, ubuntu-latest) (https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/runs/3241787882)
GitHub Actions: test (windows-latest, 3.0) (https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/runs/3241787836)

GitHub Actions: test (macos-latest, 3.0) (https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/runs/3241787637)

2021-08-04 08:18:51

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1564

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1564#issuecomment-892747102|Comment on #1564 Deprecate usage of built-in cucumber wire protocol>
<p>&gt; The change of the "AfterConfiguration" hook: is it a breaking change? If so, that mean we should release it as 8.0.0?</p> <p>OK I understand now. Yes, if we're changing the <code>AfterConfiguration</code> hook's parameter signature that's a breaking change so we'd need a major release.</p> <p>I have some concerns about exposing that whole <code>Cucumber::Glue::RegistryAndMore</code> object. The reason it has that silly name is to make it clear that it <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/main/lib/cucumber/glue/registry_and_more.rb#L42">has too many responsibilties</a>. Many of the methods on that class are really internal Cucumber stuff, so I suggest we wrap it with a Facade to limit the surface area we're exposing to users.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-08-05 00:47:42

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1564

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1564#issuecomment-893242880|Comment on #1564 Deprecate usage of built-in cucumber wire protocol>
<p>&gt; &gt; The change of the "AfterConfiguration" hook: is it a breaking change? If so, that mean we should release it as 8.0.0? &gt; &gt; OK I understand now. Yes, if we're changing the <code>AfterConfiguration</code> hook's parameter signature that's a breaking change so we'd need a major release. &gt; &gt; I have some concerns about exposing that whole <code>Cucumber::Glue::RegistryAndMore</code> object. The reason it has that silly name is to make it clear that it <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/main/lib/cucumber/glue/registry_and_more.rb#L42">has too many responsibilties</a>. Many of the methods on that class are really internal Cucumber stuff, so I suggest we wrap it with a Facade to limit the surface area we're exposing to users.</p> <p>Done<br /> Deprecation planned for v8.0<br /> Removal for v9.0</p> <p>I've also added a new RegistryWrapper which exposes only what was needed by the wire plugin: <code>create_expression</code> and <code>current_world</code></p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-08-05 00:55:12

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1566

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1566#discussion_r683217642|Comment on #1566 Upgrade rubocop>
<p>You can do this, but part of the config file is where you specify overrides,</p> <p>So you could ignore this rule on this file, and stipulate why (This "should" always be present, because it allows you to write <code>Before</code> and <code>After</code>.</p> <p>If we want to alter that, we would also have to consider altering where we allow people to write <code>ParameterType</code> e.t.c.</p>
