[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1566

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1566#discussion_r683235396|Comment on #1566 Upgrade rubocop>
<p>The only difference for this would come in a situation whereby someone is using BOTH a user-defined version of these method / lVar names and the cucumber ones. We shouldn't really look to cover that situation.</p> <p>But what I'm saying here, is instead of us just tricking rubocop, lets leave it as is, but document it in rubocop.yml by saying "This allows users to have nice DSL defined methods like ParameterType and Before in their support directory, instead of needing to instantiate new objects."</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-08-05 01:52:55

[cucumber/cucumber-rails] Comment on #514

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/issues/514#issuecomment-893419363|Comment on #514 Bug on 2.3.0 and MacOS BigSur message formatter not found>
<p><a href="https://github.com/tclaus">@tclaus</a> I had a similar issue as did another user, and we "think" that the auto-inclusion of AS with some of our code may have impacted things.</p> <p>If you try using cucumber v7+ and cucumber rails 2.4 It could make a difference (Note if you still need AS helpers, you'll need to re-include them).</p>

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1564

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1564#issuecomment-893613775|Comment on #1564 Deprecate usage of built-in cucumber wire protocol>
<p>&gt; I've also added a new RegistryWrapper which exposes only what was needed by the wire plugin: <code>create_expression</code> and <code>current_world</code></p> <p>Great. Even those two methods look like very different responsibilities, and I'm very curious why we need to be passing around a reference to the <code>current_world</code> but I think that's a rabbit hole we don't want to go down right now. Limiting this API surface seem good enough for now to me.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-08-06 01:17:12

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1564

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1564#issuecomment-894089963|Comment on #1564 Deprecate usage of built-in cucumber wire protocol>
<p>&gt; &gt; I've also added a new RegistryWrapper which exposes only what was needed by the wire plugin: <code>create_expression</code> and <code>current_world</code> &gt; &gt; Great. Even those two methods look like very different responsibilities, and I'm very curious why we need to be passing around a reference to the <code>current_world</code> but I think that's a rabbit hole we don't want to go down right now. Limiting this API surface seem good enough for now to me.</p> <p>This is because <code>wire</code> instantiate a <code>Cucumber::StepMatch</code> object: <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-wire/blob/main/lib/cucumber/wire/protocol/requests.rb#L37">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-wire/blob/main/lib/cucumber/wire/protocol/requests.rb#L37</a></p> <p>That object requires the <code>current_world</code> which it retrieves from the <code>registry</code>: <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/main/lib/cucumber/step_match.rb#L18">./lib/cucumber/step_match.rb#L18</a></p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-08-06 02:57:12

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1563

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1563#issuecomment-894148276|Comment on #1563 Which are the supported platforms?>
<p>Actually we do not support ruby 2.3 and 2.4: <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/main/cucumber.gemspec#L21">https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/main/cucumber.gemspec#L21</a></p> <p>Cucumber has been distributed to minimum ruby 2.5 since v5.0</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-08-07 00:48:04

[cucumber/cucumber-ruby] Comment on #1564

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1564#issuecomment-894978075|Comment on #1564 Deprecate usage of built-in cucumber wire protocol>
<p>&gt; &gt; &gt; I've also added a new RegistryWrapper which exposes only what was needed by the wire plugin: <code>create_expression</code> and <code>current_world</code> &gt; &gt; &gt; &gt; Great. Even those two methods look like very different responsibilities, and I'm very curious why we need to be passing around a reference to the <code>current_world</code> but I think that's a rabbit hole we don't want to go down right now. Limiting this API surface seem good enough for now to me. &gt; &gt; This is because <code>wire</code> instantiate a <code>Cucumber::StepMatch</code> object: <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-wire/blob/main/lib/cucumber/wire/protocol/requests.rb#L37">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-wire/blob/main/lib/cucumber/wire/protocol/requests.rb#L37</a> &gt; &gt; That object requires the <code>current_world</code> which it retrieves from the <code>registry</code>: <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/main/lib/cucumber/step_match.rb#L18">./lib/cucumber/step_match.rb#L18</a></p> <p>Aye, I see that.</p> <p>It just feels wrong for me for the <code>StepMatch</code> to be carrying around a (mutable) reference to the current world. It would make more sense to have whoever calls <code>args</code> pass in the <code>current_world</code> instance at the time it calls that method. But as I say, this is a rabbit hole I don't think we want to go down right now.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2021-08-10 00:42:45

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1469#issuecomment-1339800680">Comment</a> on issue by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1469|#1469 Running Scenario by line number from within Scenario doesn't work>
<p><a href="https://github.com/mattwynne">@mattwynne</a> <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a> Okay, there are two final pieces of missing functionality left to resolve this regression, and they are both related to running all the scenarios:</p> <ol><li>Specifying the line number of the <code>Feature:</code> line used to match all scenarios, now matches none.</li><li>Specifying the line number of the <code>Background:</code> line or its associated steps, used to match all scenarios, now matches none.</li> </ol> <p>I saved these two items for last, because it looks like resolving them will require changes across multiple repos. Specifically, it seems to me that the Compiler needs to pass additional info regarding the feature and background down into the core TestCase object, so that it knows to match those lines. I've made some functional exploratory spikes around this strategy, but I'm not feeling super great about any them, to be honest. Since you two are much more familiar with the codebase, do you have any high-level implementation recommendations?</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2022-12-22 21:58:12

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1684#issuecomment-1363727332">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/apps/dependabot">dependabot[bot]</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1684|#1684 Update cucumber-gherkin requirement from &gt;= 23.0.1, &lt; 25 to &gt;= 23.0.1, &lt; 27>
<p>OK, I won't notify you again about this release, but will get in touch when a new version is available. If you'd rather skip all updates until the next major or minor version, let me know by commenting <code>@dependabot ignore this major version</code> or <code>@dependabot ignore this minor version</code>. You can also ignore all major, minor, or patch releases for a dependency by adding an <a href="https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/configuration-options-for-dependency-updates#ignore"><code>ignore</code> condition</a> with the desired <code>update_types</code> to your config file.</p> <p>If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2022-12-22 23:58:47

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1695#discussion_r1066067917">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1695|#1695 Replace mime-types gem with mini_mime>
<p>If you look above on line 82 you'll see a very common media type that we log is a custom one we've invented. I'd be surprised if this was one of the cached ones in mini-mime (The docs there state that this new gem is a lot slower for uncached ones).</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2023-01-10 13:38:29

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1695#discussion_r1066371299">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/orien">orien</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1695|#1695 Replace mime-types gem with mini_mime>
<p>FYI: the <code>MiniMime.lookup_by_filename</code> call is only made if a <code>media_type</code> value <em>isn't</em> provided to the <code>attach</code> method. It's there to fill in the gap if the type isn't known ahead of time.</p> <p>The example on line 82 will not result in a call to <code>MiniMime.lookup_by_filename</code>.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2023-01-10 13:42:52

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/559#discussion_r1063972992">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/orien">orien</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/559|#559 Remove `mime-types` and `rexml` runtime dependencies>
<p>The <code>selenium-webdriver</code> uses the <code>rexml</code> library. Downstream projects only need <code>rexml</code> if they are also using the optional Selenium framework.</p> <p>The <code>selenium-webdriver</code> maintainers have added an explicit runtime dependency in version 4. This resolves the test errors when running on Ruby 3.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2023-01-06 23:59:00

*Thread Reply:*

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/559|#559 Remove `mime-types` and `rexml` runtime dependencies>
<p>Some refactoring to try and keep Rubocop happy</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2023-01-07 01:11:38

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/559#discussion_r1063979714">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/orien">orien</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/559|#559 Remove `mime-types`, `rexml`, and `webrick` runtime dependencies>
<p>Install the <code>webrick</code> gem in this step to support the optional Capybara configuration above.</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/blob/3f332f92c030de6c39ba7f2d3e526d16fca45905/features/step_definitions/cucumber_rails_steps.rb#L64">cucumber-rails/features/step<em>definitions/cucumber</em>rails_steps.rb</a></p> <p>Line 64 in &lt;/cucumber/cucumber-rails/commit/3f332f92c030de6c39ba7f2d3e526d16fca45905|3f332f9&gt;</p>

*Thread Reply:*

Review approved by <a href="https://github.com/mathieujobin">mathieujobin</a> on <a href="https://github.com/orien">orien's</a> pull request
Review on #559 Remove `mime-types`, `rexml`, and `webrick` runtime dependencies
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2023-01-10 03:13:48

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/559#discussion_r1065644733">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/559|#559 Remove `mime-types`, `rexml`, and `webrick` runtime dependencies>
<p>We still support lower ruby versions. I'm kinda on the fence about this, as ideally people should be controlling their own version constraints if they need this. So I think I'm 50-50 about this. I don't see the harm in retaining this until we're ruby 3.0+ only (Which isn't likely to be too long at current development rates).</p> <p>That being said, if you're passionate about this, I don't see the harm in making this change. It was originally made when we introduced ruby3 into our support matrix.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2023-01-10 03:13:48

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/559#discussion_r1065646265">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/559|#559 Remove `mime-types`, `rexml`, and `webrick` runtime dependencies>
<p>Wherever possible we're trying to avoid doing in-line exclusions and using the top level control with a comment explaining why.</p> <p>Ideally longer term we should compress this down a bit. But it is test only code, so it's low prio.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2023-01-10 03:13:49

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/559#discussion_r1065639670">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/559|#559 Remove `mime-types`, `rexml`, and `webrick` runtime dependencies>
<p>These references to <code>step</code> need removing actually. So I'd prefer not doing this.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2023-01-10 03:13:49

*Thread Reply:*

Reviewed and changes requested by <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a> on <a href="https://github.com/orien">orien's</a> pull request
Review on #559 Remove `mime-types`, `rexml`, and `webrick` runtime dependencies
<p>Couple of stylistic changes to make. All in all I've not got any major problems with it.</p> <p>Would be good to get your take on the ruby3 gems. I'm on the fence and didn't introduce it originally.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2023-01-10 03:13:49

2023-01-10 13:05:35

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/559#discussion_r1066347249">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/orien">orien</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/pull/559|#559 Remove `mime-types`, `rexml`, and `webrick` runtime dependencies>
<p>My argument is there is no code in the <code>cucumber-rails</code> gem that uses <code>rexml</code> or <code>webrick</code>. It operates identically, with or without these dependencies, on all supported versions of Ruby. There is no value in declaring them as runtime dependencies.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2023-01-11 01:26:15

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1524|#1524 Built-in html formatter generates a blank html report>
<p>I was able to reproduce this using Cucumber <code>--tags</code>. <code>bundle exec cucumber -t '@&amp;lt;tag_name&amp;gt;' -f html -o report.html</code> would throw a blank report but when I ran it with a Cucumber file name <code>bundle exec cucumber features/&amp;lt;file_name&amp;gt;.feature -f html -o report.html</code> I was able to view the HTML report and was not blank.</p> <p>Did a quick check in the DOM Console and found this<br /> <a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9060416/211933534-a2f4d443-3f6e-4abb-b6c7-3baa8e889fe7.png">chrome_8RoGZl4CtW</a></p> <p><a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9060416/211929221-af07ee79-f7f1-4590-8179-a19efa094ab8.png">chrome_XvO326a18A</a></p> <p>Cucumber v6.1.0<br /> Ruby v2.6.0<br /> Windows 11<br /> Browsers tried - Chrome v108x, Edge, Firefox</p>

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1701#issuecomment-1488147906">Comment</a> on issue by <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1701|#1701 Overly restrictive dependency spec on gherkin>
<p>As mentioned on the other thread. The inter-dependency rules for gherkin in the cucumber gem are required to be reasonably tightly coupled as we don't support many version/s. Usually it's pinned to 1 major but the last couple of updates haven't changed too much</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/250#issuecomment-1580205058">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/250|#250 Fix: retried scenarios which are run after another scenario with a passed result are still counted as failed>
<p>The original post sounds like quite a big bug, which has not been encountered by myself in years of running this. Can you maybe share a reproducible script that generates the failures you mention.</p> <p>The specs/tests are a little hard to follow, but I think I need a better understanding of where this error comes from first.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-06-15 03:36:05

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/250#issuecomment-1592793247">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/thukim">thukim</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/250|#250 Fix: retried scenarios which are run after another scenario with a passed result are still counted as failed>
<p>Hi <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a> ,</p> <p>&gt; The original post sounds like quite a big bug, which has not been encountered by myself in years of running this.</p> <p>Most of the time, if we use the built-in <code>--retry</code> option, it won't happen to have any issue since the failed scenario will be retried immediately, thus the condition <code>event.test_case != @previous_test_case</code> will be true.</p> <p>However, sometimes, we might want to have a custom way to retry those failed scenarios, for example: retry the failed scenarios after all the scenarios have been run. With this case, the condition <code>event.test_case != @previous_test_case</code> might not be true anymore since it only stores the last scenario to the var <code>@previous_test_case</code>, not all the scenarios which have been run previously.</p> <p>This PR improves the cucumber retry so that it works for both cases: retry immediately right after 1 failed scenario, or retry later after other scenarios too.</p> <p>&gt; Can you maybe share a reproducible script that generates the failures you mention.</p> <p>Sure, I have created <a href="https://github.com/thukim/cucumber_tests">this Github repo</a> to test - just need to run <code>bundle</code> and then <code>bundle exec cucumber</code> to reproduce it.</p> <p>I also attached the screenshots below for the differences when running the cucumber tests before and after this PR:</p> <p>Before <a href="https://github.com/thukim/cucumber_tests/blob/main/Gemfile#L73">(with cucumber-core v11.1.0)</a><br /> <a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1097697/246080499-d3b4c5fc-7a14-4f74-9e94-f536488f0996.png">Screenshot 2023-06-15 at 17 14 53</a></p> <p>After <a href="https://github.com/thukim/cucumber_tests/blob/main/Gemfile#L74">(with this PR)</a><br /> <a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1097697/246080509-ec1f4b83-0ed7-4eaf-b1af-d40e1ff9578c.png">Screenshot 2023-06-15 at 17 14 19</a></p> <p>Let me know if you have any other questions!</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-06-15 03:54:26

*Thread Reply:*

But in essence, we're not going back to the old system. *Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1443#issuecomment-1615949614">Comment</a> on issue by <a href="https://github.com/atulsarkar1">atulsarkar1</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1443|#1443 Attaching screenshots doesn't work for html reports>
<p><strong>Finally it's works for me. ✅</strong></p> <pre><code>ruby: 2.7.3 cucumber (5.3.0) </code></pre> <pre><code>After do |scenario| Dir::mkdir('screenshots') unless File.directory?('screenshots') screenshot = "./screenshots/FAILED_#{scenario.name.gsub(' ', '_').gsub(/[^0-9A-Za-z_]/, '')}.png" if scenario.failed? @browser.driver.save_screenshot(screenshot) # Read the screenshot file as binary data screenshot_data = File.read(screenshot, mode: 'rb') # Encode the screenshot data to base64 attach(screenshot_data, 'image/png') attach @browser.browser.url, 'text/html' attach get_js_errors, 'text/html' end @browser.close end </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2023-07-26 01:11:13

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1717#issuecomment-1687959448">Comment</a> on issue by <a href="https://github.com/mattwynne">mattwynne</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1717|#1717 Both Doc String and Data Table in a Step?>
<p>This isn't currently supported.</p> <p>A workaround would be to use two separate steps to capture this data from the scenario.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2023-08-22 07:43:24

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1717#issuecomment-1688326709">Comment</a> on issue by <a href="https://github.com/jenisys">jenisys</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1717|#1717 Both Doc String and Data Table in a Step?>
<p><a href="https://github.com/pgundlupetvenkatesh">@pgundlupetvenkatesh</a></p> <p>• Both DocString and DataTable for a step makes no sense for me (and is chaotic, not really readable) • Either providing a <code>DocString</code> or a <code>DataTable</code> for a step may make sometimes sense.<br /> The step implementation must support this. In this case, it can handle/process raw data as string. As alternative, it will also support structured-data provided by a DataTable. • Often, you are better served if you split-up the functionality/step-wording into two steps, one that supports the <code>DocString</code> and another step that supports the <code>DataTable</code></p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2023-08-29 01:40:47

*Thread Reply:*

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/issues/563#issuecomment-1696997162">Comment</a> on issue by <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/issues/563|#563 Simplify the default, generated Cucumber config>
<p>Whilst you are right, there is a secondary issue to consider....</p> <p>Which is for a while (I believe not on github), we've advocated from trying to move away from cucumber.yml to something more ruby like. Ideally a standardised <code>.rb</code> file. The primary reason is the <code>.yml</code> file has a "faux" erb templating parse mechanism, which isn't understood by IDEs (It throws errors up the wazoo), and also isn't particularly well documented. It is also unique to cucumber-ruby.</p> <p>If you're willing to do some minor tweaks to it, then I would gladly welcome it / review it. Currently my plan is to get a version9 cut in the coming weeks, and then I've got at least half a dozen refactor PR's. Predominantly to do with the dependencies to get out. This should see some form of patch/minor influx of releases to get caught up.</p> <p>Until the above is done, I wouldn't be willing to look at this personally.</p> <p>Hope that helps / gives some more clarity.</p> <p>NB: Be careful of using "some" YML standards in the <code>cucumber.yml</code> file. They will potentially fail. Again as mentioned, it's sort of half-yml half-erb</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2023-08-29 01:45:31

2023-09-30 08:35:10

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1341975360">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p><a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a> Yes, exactly. Its essentially a order-independent set of lines.</p> <p>So maybe it makes sense to refactor it to be an actual <code>Set</code> rather than an order-dependent <code>Array</code>?</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-09-30 08:41:47

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1341976120">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p><a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a> Makes sense to me, FWIW. It looks like the usual functional-programming strategy of "mutating" a data structure without actually mutating it, to avoid unexpected side-effects elsewhere in the program if someone else is holding onto a reference to the original data structure. Most functional languages I've used have a nice syntax for this idiom, and so this looks like a familiar pattern to my eyes.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-09-30 09:35:11

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1341985388">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p><a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a> Great question, took me a minute to figure out why. So the <code>pickle</code> variable represents a scenario, and <em>usually</em> a scenario only has one corresponding line in the document... the line that starts with <code>Scenario:</code>, so we would expect the accessor to actually be <code>#ast_node_id</code>. However, there are circumstances in which a Scenario can have multiple lines, for example:</p> <pre><code>Scenario Outline: eating Given there are &amp;lt;start&amp;gt; cucumbers When I eat &amp;lt;eat&amp;gt; cucumbers Then I should have &amp;lt;left&amp;gt; cucumbers Examples: | start | eat | left | | 12 | 5 | 7 | | 20 | 5 | 15 | </code></pre> <p>In this case, the scenario has <em>two</em> lines, the line beginning with <code>Scenario Outline:</code> and then also the line containing the values, e.g. <code>| 12 | 5 | 7 |</code>. Therefore, the pickle has to have an Array accessor of <code>#ast_node_ids</code>.</p> <p>However, in our use-case, finding the parent lines of a given scenario, we don't care which scenario line is used, because they both have the same parents, and there's always at least one, so we can just grab the first one with <code>[0]</code>.</p> <p>That's a lot of explanation! We should probably put this in the code somewhere? Maybe extract a well-named variable?</p> <pre><code> def source_lines_for_pickle_parents(pickle) first_scenario_line_ast_node_id = pickle.ast_node_ids.first # Scenario Outlines have multiple lines per scenario, but they both have the same parents gherkin_query.scenario_parent_locations(first_scenario_line_ast_node_id).map(&amp;amp;:line) end </code></pre> <p>WDYT?</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-09-30 09:44:24

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1341986170">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p>Hmm, let me think.</p> <p>a) I don't like this, because it seems like <code>locations</code> and <code>parent_locations</code> are conceptually related, so I would feel icky (technical term) to not have them physically co-located.<br /> b) I don't like this, because the data model is actually <strong>incomplete</strong> without <code>#parent_locations</code>. Omitting it in v4.0 is what led to this regression that I've been trying to fix for years!<br /> c) I think this is the "correct" way forward, but I'd suggest they should be kwargs. Most should be required, and some we could default to empty arrays, like <code>tags</code>, perhaps.</p> <p>I'm willing to take on this refactor, but I'm leaning towards doing it in a separate PR that builds on-top of this branch, to keep this PR focused. Should I proceed?</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-09-30 09:57:17

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1341987189">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/mattwynne">mattwynne</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p>Yes <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">@botandrose</a> that was the intent of this style, which is all over the place in this code. These are values, not entities.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-09-30 09:58:13

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1341987304">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p>My suggested <code>C::C::Test::Case</code> kwargs refactor would address this... unless there's a similar cop for max kwargs??</p> <p>Just checked, and its a bit of a grey area. By default, it would indeed complain about the kwargs list being too long (default is 3, whether its posargs or kwargs). However, we can set the <code>CountKeywordArgs</code> flag to <code>false</code> to not count the latter.</p> <p>Interestingly, there's a hard-coded exception carved out for constructors for <code>Struct</code> and <code>Data</code>, and I quote (emphasis mine):</p> <p>&gt; Any number of arguments for initialize method inside a block of Struct.new and Data.define is always allowed. <strong>This is because checking the number of arguments of the initialize method does not make sense.</strong></p> <p><a href="https://www.rubydoc.info/gems/rubocop/RuboCop/Cop/Metrics/ParameterLists">https://www.rubydoc.info/gems/rubocop/RuboCop/Cop/Metrics/ParameterLists</a></p> <p>So, I would assert that by RuboCop's own logic, this cop already doesn't make sense for our use-case either, so we should keep it as an explicit exception either way!</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-09-30 10:06:49

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1341988126">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p><a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a> Many of the memoized helpers (at least<code>test_id</code>, <code>step_id</code>, <code>name</code>) only exist to be used once in the constructor, and never referenced again. I think the number of <code>let</code>s could be cut down dramatically by introducing some factory methods, something like <code>#build_test_case</code> and <code>#build_test_step</code>.</p> <p>Again, though, this would be a pretty big refactor, diff-wise, for the file, so I'd like to do it on a separate follow-up PR that builds on-top of this. Proceed?</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>

2023-09-30 10:10:03

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1341988376">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p><a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a> Also realizing that switching <code>C::C::Test::Case#initialize</code> to kwargs would improve this situation all by itself, because many variables are only in <code>let</code>s just so that they're named somewhere, and aren't bare <code>double</code>s with no context. With kwargs, it would be a non-issue to just use e.g. <code>Test::Case.new(id: double, name: double, ... )</code> etc, I think.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-09-30 10:26:53

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1341989868">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p><a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a> More thoughts here.</p> <p>Ideally, we'd refactor <code>C::C::Test::Case</code> to inherit from <code>Data</code>, because it seems to me that <code>Data</code> perfectly fits its use-case and intent, as <a href="https://github.com/mattwynne">@mattwynne</a> mentioned in another comment farther down. But <code>Data</code> is Ruby 3.2+ only. We could polyfill with <a href="https://github.com/saturnflyer/polyfill-data">https://github.com/saturnflyer/polyfill-data</a>, but that's a new dependency... so maybe we could copy and paste it in-repo with some minor tweaks:</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/saturnflyer/polyfill-data/blob/main/lib/data.rb">https://github.com/saturnflyer/polyfill-data/blob/main/lib/data.rb</a></p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-10-01 08:58:49

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1342155748">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p><a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a> Taking another look at this, if we change <code>#matching_locations</code> to a <code>Set</code>, rather than an <code>Array</code>, we could just <code>pickle.ast_node_ids.flat_map(&amp;amp;:line)</code> and call it a day. Set semantics would get rid of the duplicates. Which, now that I think about it, honestly wouldn't really be an issue, if we just left it as an array. Who cares if there's duplicate lines? The array just needs to match the given line number or not.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1345594786">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1345594947">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p><a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a> Thinking about this some more, I'm going to explore extracting our own Data-like base class from all the value objects in core. I think it would alleviate a lot of the Rubocop violations, and also make things simpler. We'll see.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-10-04 21:20:36

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1346761515">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/mattwynne">mattwynne</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p><a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a> this is a well-established design pattern, described in books like Eric Evans' Domain-Driven Design or Steve Freeman/Nat Pryce's Growing Object Oriented Software Guided by Tests: Value objects (things that just contain data) should be immutable if possible.</p> <p>So if you want to be create a new value that's similar to an existing one, it's nice to have convenience methods like this that create a copy-but-with-this-field-tweaked.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-10-05 06:35:01

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1347432972">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p>I pushed a proof-of-concept PR with the base class extraction, named <code>Value</code>. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/266/files">https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/266/files</a>. Thoughts?</p> <p>P.S. <a href="https://github.com/mattwynne">@mattwynne</a> I love those two books 👍</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>

Review comment by <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a> on <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose's</a> pull request

2023-10-06 05:10:49

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1348638234">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p><a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a> I think you're right. I just pushed another commit moving more of these details into private methods. If we move to a kwargs constructor for <code>Test::Case</code> and <code>Test::Step</code> we can reduce this even further by omitting the variable assignment, which is mostly for constructor arg readability.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-10-06 05:26:12

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1348653660">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p>Looks like we're using "line" and "location" interchangeably. It's a line from a human perspective, but since this is testing the <code>Test::LocationsFilter</code> class in isolation, the parameter is a <code>Test::Location</code>, and the return is a <code>Test::Location</code>, I guess we should normalize this to "location." I'll make a pass and try to bring consistency to all the spec names, including your feedback above.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-10-06 05:59:30

<p><a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">@luke-hill</a> Seeing as this data structure is included in Ruby 3.2 -- and in <em>core</em>, not std lib -- I'd say its as standard Ruby as it gets, as standard as Hash or Set.</p> <p>We're currently supporting Ruby 2.5+, released in 2017, nearly six years ago. This is an attempt to get the benefits described above without waiting six-ish years for cucumber to require 3.2+.</p>

2023-10-27 03:03:03

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1374350538">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p>You should be able to have these 1 indented. I think the issue is the <code>[]</code> chars tripping it up.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-10-27 03:05:58

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1374353293">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p>This should work</p> <pre><code>expect(receiver.test_case_locations).to eq( [test_case_named('one').location, test_case_named('two').location] ) </code></pre> <p>Or multiline</p> <pre><code>expect(receiver.test_case_locations).to eq( [ test_case_named('one').location, test_case_named('two').location ] ) </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-10-27 03:20:08

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1374367121">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p>Honestly, I think that's worse, because its less clear that there are two elements in the array, and we lose symmetry with the multiline input arrays. For example:</p> <pre><code> it 'sorts by the given locations' do locations = [ Test::Location.new('features/test.feature', 6), Test::Location.new('features/test.feature', 3) ] ... expect(receiver.test_case_locations).to eq([ Test::Location.new('features/test.feature', 3), Test::Location.new('features/test.feature', 6) ]) end </code></pre> <p>I gotta say, I'm not super sold on Rubocop's utility, overall. I recognize the value of having an automated single style enforcer in an open source project with many different contributors, but here we are, having a style discussion anyways, despite Rubocop being here, trying to figure out how to game around it.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
GitHub
2023-10-27 03:47:44

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#discussion_r1374394562">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">botandrose</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p>Here's a concrete suggestion, rather than just me complaining :)</p> <p>How about we disable (or make an exception for) the rule that prompted the excessive indentation in the first place?</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/issues/505#issuecomment-1753438468">Comment</a> on issue by <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/issues/505|#505 Rubocop legacy fix: Erroneous Auto Inheritance of ActionDispatch::IntegrationTest in the World>
<p><a href="https://github.com/BrianHawley">@BrianHawley</a> - As a heads up. I'm going to try a small tweak, to just ensure that the class is setup correctly by calling <code>super</code> on the existing initialize method. This will alleviate rubocop and give us something to learn from - if this also causes issues then I think we might have to put more guards around any modifications here</p> <p>Now this "could" be potentially problematic. So for now I'm just going to push the branch up and invite a few people to play with it.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2023-10-13 06:52:42

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/issues/505#issuecomment-1761559859">Comment</a> on issue by <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails/issues/505|#505 Rubocop legacy fix: Erroneous Auto Inheritance of ActionDispatch::IntegrationTest in the World>
<p>As an update this branch is merged into <code>main</code></p> <p>I dug into some of the code and found the initializer was a "hack" set up 13 years ago. With the comment "Remove this". So after checking and removing it. I found that 4 levels deep the <code>super</code> call will require a <code>name</code> property. So I just added in a super call with a <code>name</code> and then from there everything else worked fine.</p> <p>This obviously doesn't fix the issue of inheriting from it, but when I removed that I found a whole word of hurt happened including things like standard rails methods (<code>model_path</code> for example), started failing.</p> <p>As such I'll keep this issue open for a couple of weeks, but then I'll close it off as no longer relevant.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-rails">cucumber/cucumber-rails</a>
GitHub
2023-10-10 10:54:28

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1738#issuecomment-1777041608">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>

<p><strong>Note for watchers</strong></p> <p>cdata fix didn't make it into 13.0.2 of the CCK, but some more inconsistencies (Not failing ones), did.</p> <p>13.0.2+ of the CCK is needed to make this PR green. ETA on getting all remaining reconciliation fixes is not yet known</p>

2023-11-02 10:55:43

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1738#discussion_r1380588108">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1738|#1738 Make cucumber CCK compliant>
<p><a href="https://github.com/ehuelsmann">@ehuelsmann</a> / <a href="https://github.com/davidjgoss">@davidjgoss</a> - This is where I'm tripping up now and cannot explain it.</p> <p>In the CCK from here (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/compatibility-kit/commit/a3546f798a0caa09715e82027608e93b83f6d0a4#diff-7df09050f374e2ce8fc33ec3c05df9b40844714d7d622da7b1a56a73fd7f10bd">cucumber/compatibility-kit@a3546f7#diff-7df09050f374e2ce8fc33ec3c05df9b40844714d7d622da7b1a56a73fd7f10bd</a>) I can see for over 2 years we've never had a message property in a <code>PENDING</code> message.</p> <p>However..... We've had little coverage of PENDING messages - just that one scenario.</p> <p>From the above you can see previously we were always treating pending steps here as requiring 3 properties (Correct on old schema - <code>status</code>, <code>duration</code> and <code>message</code>). This PR adds the fourth one for backwards compatibility.</p> <p>However it seems as though something went awry in the CCK reconciliation updates I've been doing. But I cannot spot what. It seems as though the CCK <strong>never</strong> had this <code>message</code> property set (Last 2 years).</p> <p>I probably need to explain it better. But not 100% sure where I've gone wrong / what's wrong</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
GitHub
2023-11-10 06:25:52

To ignore this dependency forever, add it to the <code>ignoreDeps</code> array of your Renovate config.</p> <p>If you accidentally closed this PR, or if you changed your mind: rename this PR to get a fresh replacement PR.</p>

<p>Hi <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">@botandrose</a>,</p> <p>Thanks for your making your first contribution to Cucumber, and welcome to the Cucumber committers team! You can now push directly to this repo and all other repos under the cucumber organization! 🍾</p> <p>In return for this generous offer we hope you will:</p> <p>• ✅ Continue to use branches and pull requests. When someone on the core team approves a pull request (yours or someone else's), you're welcome to merge it yourself. • 💚 Commit to setting a good example by following and upholding our <a href="https://cucumber.io/conduct">code of conduct</a> in your interactions with other collaborators and users. • 💬 Join the <a href="http://cucumber.io/support#slack">community Slack channel</a> to meet the rest of the team and make yourself at home. • ℹ️ Don't feel obliged to help, just do what you can if you have the time and the energy. • 🙋 Ask if you need anything. We're looking for feedback about how to make the project more welcoming, so please tell us!</p> <p>On behalf of the Cucumber core team,<br /> Aslak Hellesøy<br /> Creator of Cucumber</p>

<p>Hey Matt, thank you very much! That's such a nice message to receive. I definitely enjoyed pairing with you on this a year ago or so, so thanks for that, as well!</p> <p>Cucumber is one of the mainstays of my dev toolbox, and I'm happy to keep investing back into it, and I'll certainty continue to do so when I run into issues myself.</p> <p>I was toying with the idea of expanding my involvement with Cucumber, and making a habit of spending a few hours every weekend contributing beyond addressing my own issues. But I have to admit that a few factors have got me feeling a bit discouraged.</p> <ol><li>Negative response to my last refactoring PR.</li><li>Length of time from submitting this PR to it finally getting merged.</li><li>Length of code review process.</li> </ol> <p>I don't want to imply that there has been anything but superb conduct from anyone! I'm in no way feeling that anything was unjust or incorrect or bad or wrong. But I'm simply more motivated to work on projects where I can ship more code more quickly.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>

*Thread Reply:*

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247#issuecomment-1819503947">Comment</a> on pull request by <a href="https://github.com/mattwynne">mattwynne</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/247|#247 Teach Cucumber::Core::Test::Case to match on parent locations.>
<p>I appreciate the feedback <a href="https://github.com/botandrose">@botandrose</a>, and yes I enjoyed pairing with you too.</p> <p>As Luke says we've been though a bit of a <a href="https://mattwynne.net/new-beginning">tumultuous time</a> recently, and although that situation is hopefully drawing to a close, it has been quite disruptive and distracting for us. Sorry if you didn't get the attention you needed.</p> <p>One thing I would say, in reference to being able to ship stuff, is that we encourage everyone with commit rights to the <code>main</code> branches to follow the <a href="https://martinfowler.com/articles/ship-show-ask.html">Ship / Show / Ask</a> protocol. In other words, while code reviews can be a great way to get buy-in or feedback on bigger changes you're not sure about, you're absolutely encouraged to just commit directly to <code>main</code> or merge your own PRs as long as you feel the changes are generally moving us forwards.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>
